results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Echuca’, captures a visit to the township of Echuca on the Murray River in Victoria as well as travels along the river itself. Wallace focuses on travelling the river and also on the historic buildings in Echuca itself.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Ehuca’
00:00:20:00 paddle steamer travelling on the Murray River.
00:01:26:00 to 00:02:50:00 historic public buildings and houses around Echuca township
00:01:53:00 historic ‘Log Buggy’ in Echuca which holds a felled log from the nearby Moira Forest
00:03:04:00 steam rollers in Echuca
00:04:22:00 Echuca-Moama Bridge over the Murray River
00:05:02:00 motor traffic and streets in Echuca
00:05:04:00 St Mary’s Catholic Church in Echuca
00:05:39:00 Paddle Steamer Adelaide, berthed as an exhibit in the Hopwood Gardens in Echuca, in the 1960s
00:07:58:00 passengers on a paddle steamer on the river
00:08:55:00 water skiing on the river
00:09:03:00 ‘Weir & Lock No 26’ at Torrumbarry
00:10:07:00 logging and sawmill on the riverbank
00:12:35:00 open fire barbeque and picnic on the riverbank
00:13:59:00 examples of fungi along the river
00:14:50:00 group gathering with guitarist at dusk

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures Mount Buller and surrounds, in Victoria during the summer period. There are views of the mountains, trees and wildflowers, a river and people walking and picnicking.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:45:00 cut logs on a truck.
00:03:26:00 walkers reach the Mount Buller summit.
00:07:27:00 walkers scrambling through bush and fallen trees.
00:07:51:00 several women sitting on a large log.
00:10:34:00 people walking through very tall trees show the scale of the trees growth.
00:10:55:00 a river view through the mountain landscape.
00:11:22:00 roadside picnic.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Mountains of Mystery’, contains a trip around The Grampians National Park in Victoria. The filmmaker captures the various activities of visitors to the Grampians area as well as views across the mountains, an occasional bee, lizard, snake and echidna, trees, bush and wildflowers as well as the overall rocky terrain.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Mountains of Mystery’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:22:00 hikers on top of a huge log across a creek.
00:01:57:00 an echidna hiding in the bush.
00:02:05:00 hikers walking along a bush track.
00:07:20:00 instruction card for walkers and hikers.
00:07:55:00 sign to various locations in the Park.
00:08:06:00 hikers climbing up trails and narrow ravines among dramatic grey rocky outcrops followed by views from the summit.
00:09:57:00 a koala asleep in a tree
00:10:02:00 an intrepid hiker perched precariously on a high narrow rock ledge
00:10:39:00 plaque for ‘Makefing Reserve’ near the Grampians
00:11:00:00 signpost for ‘Makefing Rd’ (in two directions) and ‘Emmet Rd’ and ‘Stockyard…’ (which could be a sign to ‘Stockyard Hill’
00:11:19:00 park sign for ‘Major Mitchell Plateau’, ‘Mt William’, ‘Jimmy Creek’
00:12:29:00 hikers preparing a couple of ‘billy cans’ of tea and/or food on a small open fire
00:12:59:00 a hiker in all red gear including a woollen cap with a ‘pom pom’
00:13:45:00 scenes of hikers on steep tracks and then views from the summit
00:15:12:00 hikers gather around a boiling ‘billy’ on a small fire
00:15:40:00 sitting enjoying their tea
00:16:25:00 and echidna hiding in the grass
00:16:37:00 tree ferns followed by an old, plank footbridge over a creek
00:16:57:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film the ‘Walkabouters’ go to Werribee Gorge State Park in Victoria for one of their walks. On this visit, they see spiders, flowers and fungi, look for rock samples and do some fence making and tree planting.

A particular point of interest is an early Coolabah brand wine cask. Established in 1962, Orlando Coolabah was one of the first commercially successful cask wine brands in Australia and very popular in the 1970s. The wine cask itself was invented and perfected in Australia, initially by Angoves Wines in South Australia.

This film also shows some mushrooms and the practice of ‘mushrooming’ in grassy farm paddocks, equipped with buckets and knives.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:34:00 close-up of a moth on a leaf
00:00:38:00 large mushrooms in a grassy paddock
00:00:46:00 a woman slicing the mushrooms from the ground and collecting in a bucket
00:01:07:00 a largish spider runs up a canvas tent wall and the underside of a mushroom
00:01:22:00 peeling a large mushroom
00:01:52:00 a Coolabah brand wine cask and a poodle dog, mushrooms cooked on a camp stove
00:02:10:00 climbing over a stile in a fence
00:02:53:00 hikers climbing and helping each other over a rocky part of the trail
00:03:07:00 close-up of a spider in its web
00:04:07:00 descending a steep rock face
00:05:49:00 a iridescent blue and green beetle, tree lichen and a brown spider in its web
00:06:09:00 perfect light brown mushroom soon followed by another species of mushroom
00:06:54:00 several spiders on their webs
00:07:42:00 a variety of leather mushrooms
00:08:30:00 likely Ambicodamus crinitus spider
00:09:13:00 sign ‘Werribee Gorge’
00:09:30:00 hikers group sitting on the edge of a rocky cliff looking at the view, including a woman with binoculars
00:11:18:00 koala in close-up and and then climbing a tree
00:11:40:00 soaring Australian wedge-tailed eagle
00:12:07:00 group of (likely) bombadier beetles in green leaves
00:12:52:00 crossing the creek rock by rock
00:13:05:00 a small brown frog (likely litoria paraewingi)
00:13:12:00 hikers take a break - cameras, snacks and beer
00:15:02:00 overlooking tents at the camping site
00:15:17:00 wading the creek and a hiker rests with his dog on a hillside
00:15:55:00 leaf impressions on the rocks
00:16:36:00 1970s style cars - station wagons and camping van
00:16:55:00 two men using a manual post hole digger followed by scenes of fence making
00:17:29:00 planting new trees

Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film the ‘Walkabouters’ go to Werribee Gorge State Park in Victoria for one of their walks. On this visit, they see spiders, flowers and fungi, look for rock samples and do some fence making and tree planting.

A particular point of interest is an early Coolabah brand wine cask. Established in 1962, Orlando Coolabah was one of the first commercially successful cask wine brands in Australia and very popular in the 1970s. The wine cask itself was invented and perfected in Australia, initially by Angoves Wines in South Australia.

This film also shows some mushrooms and the practice of ‘mushrooming’ in grassy farm paddocks, equipped with buckets and knives.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

After his signature opening title, ‘Round About Alice’, Wallace goes to the desert landscape around Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory, including close-ups of wildflowers and distance shots of ‘Mount Conner’. We see Alice Springs streets and landmarks, and the annual (since 1970) ‘Alice Springs Lions Club Camel Cup’ race. Features the historic Alice Springs Telegraph Station (1872), once also the site of ‘The Bungalow’ school, (1932-1942) for children then identified by government as ‘part aboriginal’. Wallace then films in the dramatic landscape of the ‘McDonnell Ranges’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Round About Alice’, ‘A W.H.C film’.
00:01:10:00 classic Australian style windmill spinning in wind
00:01:14:00 Mount Conner in distance
00:03:26:00 Street scenes Alice Springs
00:03:47:00 John Flynn Memorial Church, Alice Springs, exterior and interior.
00:04:31:00 extended sequence of camel racing, including scenes of watching crowd, a Scottish pipe band, and particpants in fancy dress
00:07:21:00 night sequence with illumintaed ‘Lions Cup’ sign with outline of a camel in lihghts; fireworks
00:08:02:00 Anzac Hill War Memorial (dedicated 1934) at Alice Springs, followed by aerial views of the town
00:08:32:00 Alice Springs Telegraph Station buildings and surrounds
00:09:15:00 Gravestones in the Alice Springs Telegraph Station Cemetery
00:09:58:00 John Flynn gravesite memorial
00:10:19:00 Roadsign for Simpsons Gap followed by scenes of and in McDonnell Ranges, including camping activities.

results.brief_description:

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip made by the ‘Walkabouters’ to the Wyperfeld National Park in northwestern Victoria. Wallace as usual focuses on the landscape, flora and fauna and in doing so, captures the arid beauty of the region. A highlight of the film is the usually hard to find malleefowl (or hen), an endangered bird in Victoria that Wallace films in its dry, inland scrub habitat. The malleefowl is a mound builder which, unlike any other birds in Australia, uses its large strong feet to create enormous mounds of soil in which their eggs are incubated, heated by the sun or rotting leaves.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles, ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Wyperfeld’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:33:00 a paddock of grazing sheep
00:00:46:00 a sign for ‘Wyperfeld National Park National Parks Service’ and some wildflowers
00:01:27:00 a malleefowl at work on top of its mound, followed by more wildflowers
00:02:08:00 emus
00:02:28:00 chopping fallen logs
00:02:58:00 a brown beetle
00:03:12:00 walkers on a walking track in the Park
00:03:28:00 a bird in a eucalypt (gumtree)
00:04:01:00 sandy terrain and wildflowers
00:05:34:00 a scary looking banksia plant seed pod close-up followed by more examples of banksia pods
00:06:17:00 the ‘Walkerbouters’ itinerary on a black board, including daily destinations and when to carry lunch
00:06:30:00 views of the landscape around the Park and what is likely to be a variety of blue-tongue lizard
00:08:23:00 the walkers’ campsite and another blackboard itinerary notice
00:09:33:00 the walkers rest on a large, fallen tree log
00:11:05:00 birds flying overhead
00:12:38:00 a particularly wide trunk eucalypt (gumtree) tree in the Park attracts the walkers’ attention
00:13:38:00 sandy dune-like mounds throughout the Park
00:14:18:00 walking under what appears to be old tea tree branches and possibly saltbush among more close-ups of wildflowers

The malleefowl is a mound builder which, unlike any other birds in Australia, uses its large strong feet to create enormous mounds of soil in which their eggs are incubated, heated by the sun or rotting leaves.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group walking trip by members of the ‘Walkabouters’ club to the Grampians (Gariwerd) in Victoria. It features the making of a ‘pit oven’ style barbeque and showcases the walking to be had by visitors through the many ravines and paths but also the grandeur of the sweeping views from what can seem like perilous pinnacles and lookouts.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Dreaming Place’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 views of the Grampians range off in the distance
00:00:56:00 driving through a small township
00:02:51:00 creating a ‘pit oven’ by setting a fire in a deep hole in the ground
00:02:59:00 stones are thrown into the flames and then covered with pieces of terracotta tiles on which meat in aluminium foil is placed for cooking
00:03:38:00 the pit is covered with a piece of metal, hessian bags, stones and dirt
00:04:15:00 a woman climber is helped to the top of some rocks
00:06:10:00 cars driving along a dirt road in the bush
00:06:44:00 an example of the the beautiful rock of the Grampians
00:07:07:00 sign for ‘Forest Commision of Victoria’ ‘Camp of the Emu’s Foot’
00:07:15:00 Indigenous art on rock walls
00:09:48:00 a still river which runs under a wooden walk bridge among tall reeds
00:10:19:00 a fenced off shallow cavern possibly with Indigenous drawings on the rock
00:10:35:00 views of Indigenous drawings up close
00:11:07:00 driving through the bush
00:11:54:00 grey patchy granite rock of the Grampians
00:12:29:00 a lone walker stands on top of a high peak
00:15:25:00 walking through the bush
00:17:00:00 groups of kangaroos and emus
00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians
